item.title: [EMMTC-79] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Radial spreading of downward plume hitting the sea floor
item.description:
Test cases created in the Test Case repository: fb1296_radial_spreading_of_material_at_sea_bottom

Test description
A test on whether the near-zone model behaves properly, in the sense that when a plume is directed downwards to the sea bottom, the material should be spreading out radially uniform (circle).

Acceptance criteria
NB: The pictures mentioned below are located in the location folder.

  • Observe that the spreading of particulate matter (droplet particles) is circular and uniform the first six minutes. See picture: uniform_radial_spread.png
  • Observe that the height of the particlulate matter spreading along the sea floor is similar to the maximum plume width. See picture: parable_spreading.png
  • Observe that particle matter release (radial_spreading_drilling.prv) and produced water (radial_spreading_produced_water.prv) produce identical results.

Dependencies
Current data is located in the corresponding folder.
Chemical database with release profile is located under the Databases folder.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Radial spreading of downward plume hitting the sea floor

comments.comment: Test failed. The radial spread is less than in 6.5.

item.title: [EMMTC-76] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Bug #1 in smoothing/contouring tool: northern half of surface slick disappears
item.description:
1. Run a scenario which has an oil slick on the surface.
    • View Surface grids -> Emulsion thickness.
    • Apply contouring
    • Observe that the entire slick is visible, not cut in half. (See attached screenshots.)
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Bug #1 in smoothing/contouring tool: northern half of surface slick disappears

item.title: [EMMTC-97] TEST 6.6 RC1 - statistical OSCAR: Hangs on Create Results: Computation did not complete!
item.description:
Test 1:

  1. Create a stochastic scenario with a habitat grid of 1000x1000 grid cells. Specify a vertical resolution of 20 cells.
  2. Attempt to start a stochastic simulation.
  3. Observe an error message.

Test 2:

  1. Change the vertical resolution to 10.
  2. Attempt to start a stochastic simulation.
  3. Observe that the stochastic simulation runs.
  4. Create stochastic output.
  5. Observe that there are no error messages when creating stochastic output.
  6. Observe that this creates stochastic output that can be viewed in MEMW.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - statistical OSCAR: Hangs on Create Results: Computation did not complete!

comments.comment:
Fails at vertical resolution of 10.
Vertical resolution of 9 succeeds.
Known issues, will have to be fixed properly at a later date

item.title: [EMMTC-92] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Nordland testcase OSCAR
item.description:
Test procedure

  1. Copy folder Norge_test_nordland (from I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_OSCAR) into the loc_data folder in your (local) MEMW workspace
  2. Open the TEST1MEMWX.XNordlandVI.osc scenario in MEMW and save with new version number and beta date
    • Select chem and oil databases from your Norge_test_nordland folder.
    • Copy species database to your Databases folder in your MEMW workspace.
  3. Check the profile. Should be "BALDER 2001" and make sure the oil is also "BALDER 2001"
  4. Update the wind path so it points to your Norge_test_nordland/winds folder
  5. Update the currents path so it points to your Norge_test_nordland/currents folder
  6. Copy the *.gis files from your Norge_test_nordland/gis folder into the Species folder in your MEMW workspace
  7. Open the Species Editor under the System menu and make sure the CodTest species is selected
  8. Then select CODSPAWN under Spawning Areas and press edit and make sure the information is correct (both should be "CODSPAWN"). Check that the dates are the same (Feb 15; March 15) as the ones in the MEWMX.X_releasetest_OSCAR_Nordland.docx document.
  9. Then go to the Setup menu and choose Scenario Parameters,just press next until you get to the Biological Exposure one, and make sure the box for CodTest is ticked under Species.
  10. Run the simulation. When you get the run model dialog, make sure the biological exposure box is ticked and press yes.
  11. Repeat steps 2, 10 and 11 for the Test2* and Test3* scenarios, and make sure to save them with new names.

Acceptance criteria

  • After the scenarios have been run, update the newest document MEMWX.X_releasetest_OSCAR_Nordlandyyyymmdd (X.X=version number, yyyy=year, mm=month, dd=day) found here:
    I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_OSCAR\Documentation
  • Rename it with the test version and date of the release candidate.

List of tables and figures to update (for all three cases):

  1. Mass balance (at the end of the simulation) on page 1 of the document
  2. Screenshot (at the end of the simulation) with submerged, dissolved and surface particles activated together with the mass balance, shoreline hits, mean concentration and wind arrow activated.
  3. Same as number 2, but with sediment concentration/deposition activated instead of mean concentration.
  4. Mass balance diagram (from Memw.xls)
  5. Number exposed (biology, BIOXSum.txt file from Modelout - made with Nordland-BioSum-MEMWX.X.xls)
  6. Fraction killed (biology, BIOXSum.txt file from Modelout - made with Nordland-BioSum-MEMWX.X.xls))
  7. Body residue (biology, BIOXSum.txt file from Modelout - made with Nordland-BioSum-MEMWX.X.xls)
  8. Fraction killed vs fraction of population (biology, *BIOXLog.txt file from Modelout - made with Matlab)
  • To update the biology figures from the *BIOXSum.txt file, open the file in Excel, use the "Text-to-column" function and copy&paste all the data into the Nordland-BioSum-MEMWX.X.xls file (X.X=version number - use save as with the new version number).
  • Copy the loc_data folder Norge_test_Nordland to the corresponding MEMW version folder - example I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\MEMW 6.5\Test_results\OSCAR
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Nordland testcase OSCAR

comments.comment:
Fates dialogue box shows nothing, but the results seems to be there anyway.
Running test 1 (no info in fates box).
Test 2 stops Fates (before simulation starts)....
Test 3 crashes Fates: "Permission to access file denied, unit 206, file .....hdr" - or when tried again same problem as for test 2.

item.title: [EMMTC-106] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Implement State-of-the-Art SINTEF droplet size distribution algorithm
item.description:
Tests created under the Test Case repository: fb752_updated_droplet_size_model
Test Case repository can be found here: I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\TestCases

Test description:
The improved droplet size model implemented in OSCAR 6.5 change the way droplets are calculated in the Plume3D model. In addition to rate of flow, outlet dimension and oil-water interfacial tension, viscosity now comes into play. This test has three deep water scenarios, one with pure oil, one with oil and gas, and one with an interfacial tension lowered by a factor of 200 to simulate dispersant injection.

Acceptance criteria:
For each of the three cases, open the corresponding .p3d.log file and confirm that the reported 95 percentile droplet size (D95) is reported as following:

  • 4500_tonnes_per_day 3.327 mm
  • 4500_tonnes_per_day_GOR_100 1.263 mm
  • 4500_tonnes_per_day_low_interfacial_tension 0.844 mm

Dependencies
Oil type is from the default database.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Implement State-of-the-Art SINTEF droplet size distribution algorithm

item.title: [EMMTC-81] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Installation MEMW 6.5 did not deliver any depth databases
item.description:
Test description for identifying whether a depth database has been installed with the installation:

  1. Create a new scenario for a selected location.
  2. Setup -> Habitats and depths... -> New grid
  3. Select a region by drag and drop, choose 1000m resolution in x- and y-direction.
  4. Select "Use database (with fallback)"
  5. Observe that a grid has been created without any error messages.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Installation MEMW 6.5 did not deliver any depth databases

item.title: [EMMTC-83] TEST 6.6 RC1 - User cannot add gas rate/GOR to a simulation shorter than 1 day
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Create a scenario, duration 0.1 day and release for 0.1 day.
  2. Add a gas release rate, GOR = 100, duration 0.1 day.
  3. Observe that there is no error message: "total gas release duration must not exceed oil release duration".
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - User cannot add gas rate/GOR to a simulation shorter than 1 day

item.title: [EMMTC-74] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Oil passes through land when released within 10 km of a thin strip of land
item.description:
Brief description:
This test case is to make sure oil behaves correctly when the release site is
very close to land (within 10 km). Before this bug was fixed, such a release
could allow oil to pass through a narrow strip of land.
Test scenario:
Location Northern Europe
Wind 5 m/s towards west
Current None
Wind induced current Off
Use the scenario, wind and habitat grid attached to this case for convenience.
Pass criteria:
Run the scenario. Look at the output as Surface particles, Submerged particles and
Dissolved particles. Confirm that the result look like Screenshots/pass.png,
and not like Screenshots/fail.png.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Oil passes through land when released within 10 km of a thin strip of land

item.title: [EMMTC-90] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Reading input PNEC values that are very low
item.description:
Test description
DREAM

  • Åpne scenariet Test-case under Cases i Northern Europe lokasjon.
    I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_OSCAR\Northern Europe
  • Profilen til caset er EIF-test, åpne denne og legg til en komponent EIF_OSPAR_Dibenzo(a,h)anthracene, konsentrasjon eks. 1 ppm.
  • Kjør simuleringen
  • Gå til tools -> Create Risk map
  • Velg Risk for water column

Acceptance criteria

  • Se at du får Risk maps successfully created og risk calculations completed
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Reading input PNEC values that are very low

item.title: [EMMTC-102] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Update default values for droplet size prediction of subsea releases
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Create a new OSCAR scenario.
  2. Place any release, and specify any oil.
  3. Look at the Nearfield tab.
  4. Observe that the "Size-spread Parameter" is set to 1.8 (or 1.79999), not 2.5
  5. Go to Setup -> Model parameters ... -> Near Field Models
  6. Observe that "Minimum void fraction for Mist Flow" is set to 1, not 0.95.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Update default values for droplet size prediction of subsea releases

item.title: [EMMTC-98] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Sediment test no. 1
item.description:
Test description

  1. Download the attached DREAM scenario and the habitat files, and put them in the appropriate locations.
  2. Go to System -> Component editor..., select Database -> New and choose Chemical component.
  3. Create the component LUBR-3 with data as shown in the attached screenshot.
  4. Confirm that the model parameters are as shown in the attached screenshots. Run the simulation.
  5. Go to Tools -> Create risk map..., select Risk for sediments, Momentary and time-averaged risk and press Go, then close when the calculation is done.

In this scenario, the sediment grid has only one cell. The sediment thickness is averaged over this cell, and the scenario is designed so that this thickness becomes 30 mm.

Test procedure:

  1. Confirm that the sediment thickness is 30 mm (view sediment thickness, go to end of simulation, use inspect tool).
  2. Go to Output -> Sediment Risk Stressors -> Oxygen change. Use the time series tool, and click inside the grid cell to view the series. Confirm that it looks like the attached screenshot.
    The explanation for this graph is as follows: During drilling, the addition of drill cuttings cause additional oxygen to be mixed into the sediment, causing the early high value. When the drilling is finished, the breakdown of organic chemicals present in the discharge consume oxygen, lowering the oxygen content of the sediment. When all of these are gone, diffusion will replace the oxygen, causing a slow return to the "default" level of oxygen content.
  3. Go to Output -> Sediment Risk Stressors -> Concentrations. Use the time series tool, and click inside the grid cell to view the series. Confirm that it looks like the attached screenshot.
    The explanation for this graph is that the breakdown of contaminants will proceed at a slower rate as time proceeds, because the chemicals in the top of the sediment layer are broken down first, and then the contaminants further down will take more time since the process requires oxygen, and oxygen needs to diffuse down through the sediment.
  4. Go to Output -> Risk Calculation Results -> Sediment Risk -> Oxygen Change. Use the time series tool, and click inside the grid cell to view the series. Confirm that it looks like the attached screenshot.
    The explanation for this graph is essentially the same as for the Oxygen change curve, as it shows the risk caused by Oxygen change.
  5. Go to Tools -> Open MEMW.xls. In the Excel sheet, go to Add-Ins, click MEMW -> New scenario, select the correct location and scenario, activate the radio button for Total risk in sediment, press Accept Values. View the Time development chart showing EIFs, confirm that it looks like the attached screenshot.
    • If you have trouble with MEMW.xls take a look at this page on the wiki: https://stegosaurus.sintef.no/wiki/index.php/Viewing_and_Further_Processing_Results#Spreadsheet_Graphics

The explanation for this graph (note the non-linear time axis) is that at first, the risk is dominated by the presence of the contaminant LUBR-3, and the thickness of the sediment. Then, the contaminant is broken down, leading to a fall in oxygen levels, and risk is dominated by oxygen change and sediment thickness. Eventually, oxygen levels start returning to normal, and the only remaining factor is the thickness of the sediment.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Sediment test no. 1

item.title: [EMMTC-89] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Gas release test case: BigDog
item.description:
Test description
MEMW 6.4 was tested against DeepBlow (Plume3D stand alone) as we had the BigMadDog project where we ran calculations with DeepBlow and the MEMW6.4 project in parallel.
find attached two Excel table, one showing the setup for a transient case (gas and oil rate changing over time due to closing valve and decreasing pressure in pipeline) the other showing the results from the test.

The main difference between oil spills and gas releases is the resolution. While oil spills go on for a while and the oil slick might spread over a wide area, gas releases are fast and either get trapped (do not reach the surface at all) or have a surfacing area of several km only. Therefor the time step is supposed to be small enough. To assure enough particles in each surface grid cell for further processing of the gas flux (avoid patchiness) one should use many particles (30000) with a rather coarse grid.

Notes:

  • DeepBlow was run without currents for these cases, so might always find a deviation in the downstream displacement (which by the way is X [m] in DeepBlow but Y(m) in MEMW!)
  • There is a strong deviation in the reported void fraction which is due to the gridding in MEMW (contacted Øistein on that)

Dependencies

  • FInd location with test cases at I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_OSCAR\Gas track testing
  • The results from the last test are in the modelout folder.
  • You will need a MEMW_GASTRACK license to test the gas track features.
  • You will need a keys database containing the key for void fraction and mass flux.
  • You will need to zoom in (ca. until 50km) to be able to see the results of the gas blowout.

Test method:

  1. Run scenarios (update and use the batch file).
  2. compare the results from protocol <scenario>.p3d found in the modelout folder with the results reported in the Excel sheet attached below.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Gas release test case: BigDog

comments.comment: Everything looks as it sould be, need to check void fraction.

item.title: [EMMTC-87] TEST 6.6 RC1 - TEST 6.6 RC1 - Ice handling
item.description:
Test description
A test on whether OSCAR takes ice into account or not.
Procedure

  1. Update output interval to 10 minutes
  2. Update wind and current pointer files to reflect your MEMW location
  3. Run impacted area calculation (Tools->Computed Impacted Area/Volume), only check the Surface Oil Thickness box
  4. Look at the Overall maximum surface oil thickness (Output > Impacted Area/Volume > Surface Oil Thickness).

Acceptance criteria

  • Observe that the oil slick follows the pattern in the figure below:
    (If OSCAR didn't take ice into account, the spill would only go northeast and 'stop' there.)

Dependencies
Complete scenario (incl oil db and chem db) is located in:
I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_OSCAR\Norge_FEX09
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - TEST 6.6 RC1 - Ice handling

item.title: [EMMTC-104] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Possible to create drilling site with a valid ParTrack licence
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Ensure that you have a valid ParTrack license: The file MEMW_PARTRACK.LEF must be located in either your program folder or the workspace folder. Observe that you have no message indicating that your ParTrack license has expired when you start MEMW.
  2. Create a DREAM scenario.
  3. Create drilling sites:
    • Create a drilling site with the drilling tower button in the lower left.
    • Create a drilling site with the menu option Setup > Scenario parameters... > Add > Drill site
    • Create a drilling site with the menu option Setup > Drill site > Manually
  4. Observe that all three methods 3a to 3c results in a created drilling site.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Possible to create drilling site with a valid ParTrack licence

item.title: [EMMTC-105] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Particle does not follow Plume trajectory if sink/rise time is shorter than time step
item.description:
Test case created in the test case repository as fb690_teleportation_bug.
Test case repository:
I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\TestCases

Test procedure

  • The bug shows up at the fourth timestep (minute 24) for the dissolved particles.
  • Particles appear detached from the rest of the bulk in north-east direction.
  • Note that the profile has to be an agent like EIF-test or acetone.

Images below for BUG and for OK respectively.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Particle does not follow Plume trajectory if sink/rise time is shorter than time step

item.title: [EMMTC-70] TEST 6.6 RC1 - "Lab Data" field in "Select oil" window incorrectly constructed from database
item.description:
Simple test – acceptance criteria:
Check that "Balder 2001" has labdata set to "yes" in the OSCAR dialog window
More comprehensive test (optional):
Compare the oil list in OSCAR with the oil types in the FRACTION table in oildb.mdb.
All oiltypes in the FRACTION table should have labdata set to "yes" in OSCAR.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - "Lab Data" field in "Select oil" window incorrectly constructed from database

item.title: [EMMTC-94] TEST 6.6 RC1- Drilling test: Basecase sensitivity
item.description:
Test description
This test has four parts, described in four different sections of this case. This was done to group the attached images closer to the relevant test descriptions.
All images in this case is taken from the 6.5 beta. In compiling the test case, I have compared with the same images from the 6.2 release (these images can be found in the Word file available at "I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_DREAM\Testing Drilling.docx".
All the images are quite close, but not identical, between the two versions.

Test procedure

  1. Copy the location "Testcase-Release Drilling" as well as the chimcal db "chemdb-drilling-test-nov08.mdb"
  2. Copy the documents with the results "Testing Drilling.docx" from:
    I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_DREAM\
  3. Open the document and look at the index to see what scenarios should be run.

Visual comparison - Sediment and particles:

  1. Display sediment thickness. Move to end of simulation, which should be at 3644 days, 19 hours and 25 minutes. Compare to image below.
  2. Display sediment mass/area. Move to end of simulation, which should be at 3644 days, 19 hours and 25 minutes. Compare to image below.
  3. Display sediment grainsize. Move to end of simulation, which should be at 3644 days, 19 hours and 25 minutes. Compare to image below.
  4. Display submerged particles. Move simulation to 1 day 12 hours. Display particles using a fixed size of 3 pixels. Place a vertical cross section with depth from 0 to 100 meters approximately as shown. Compare to image below.
    Note that in 6.2, there was a bug which caused all particles to be shown with the same colour when shown with fixed size.

MEMW.xls: Sediment Risk:

  1. Go to Tools -> Create Risk Map.... Select Risk for sediment, using double sided risk cuve. Select momentary and time averaged risk. Press Go, then close when the calculation is finished.
  2. Go to Tools -> Open MEMW.xls. Set loc_data to point to the location folder holding the output, go to the tab named Add ins, select MEMW and New workbook. Select the correct scenario, select Total risk in sediment, and press Accept Values.
  3. Find the tab named Graph 1 - Time development EIFs and confirm that the plot looks like the attached image.
  4. Find the tab named Chart_totsed. Timestep should be set to All, and EIFs should be set to All.
  5. Confirm that the values in the table are similar to those shown in the attached image.

MEMW.xls: Water column risk:

  1. Go to Tools -> Create Risk Map.... Select risk for Water Column, including particulate materials. Select momentary and time averaged risk. Press Go, then close when the calculation is finished.
  2. Go to Tools -> Open MEMW.xls. Set loc_data to point to the location folder holding the output, go to the tab named Add ins, select MEMW and New workbook. Select the correct scenario, select Water column risk, and press Accept Values.
  3. Find the tab named Graph 1 - Time development EIFs and confirm that the plot looks like the attached image.
  4. Find the tab named Chart_watcol. Timestep should be set to All, and EIFs should be set to All.
  5. Confirm that the values in the table are similar to those shown in the attached image.

Visual comparison - Risk:

  1. Go to Tools -> Create Risk Map.... Select risk for Water Column, including particulate materials. Select Risk for sediment, using double sided risk cuve. Select momentary and time averaged risk. Press Go, then close when the calculation is finished.
  2. Select Output -> Risk calculation results ->Water column risk -> Total risk. Move the simulation to the end, which will display a total risk summary. Confirm that the output looks similar to the attached image.
  3. Select Output -> Risk calculation results ->Sediment risk -> Total risk. Move the simulation to the end, which will display a total risk summary.
  4. Confirm that the output looks similar to the attached image.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1- Drilling test: Basecase sensitivity

item.title: [EMMTC-72] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Strange release of particles long time after release end
item.description:
Test cases created under the Test Case repository: fb1236_incorrect_spillet_placement

Test description
----------------

A bug was fixed in 6.5 which affects the results: Oil leaking from the shore was artificially created near the release point instead of at the shoreline cell.

This test describes a short surface release being transported onto the beach with low wind strength and currents.
After beaching, the wind reverses and oil leaks from the shoreline. The main bulk of oil is transported outside the grid,
while the shoreline continues to leak.

Acceptance criteria
-------------------

Observe that the main bulk of oil is transported to the beachline, then transported back to the sea and north-west outside the grid.
Observe that dissolved oil, submerged and surface spillets are not created from the release point after the oil has hit shoreline.

Dependencies
------------

Winds and currents are located in the corresponding folders.
Oil type is from the default database.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Strange release of particles long time after release end

item.title: [EMMTC-77] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Fates does not read the file from the UDUNITS-PATH in the scenario .cfg file
item.description:
How to test:

  1. Create a runnable scenario in MEMW
  2. Run the scenario (or at least create the .cfg file)
  3. Run Fates from the command line "fates.exe "path-to-.cfg-file"
  4. Observe that all is well
  5. Edit the .cfg file to make the path for the UDUNITS-PATH key invalid
    • OR change the name of the target udunits.dat file itself, to for example udunits.dut
  6. Repeat step 3)
  7. Observe that Fates gives a warning in the log that he cannot find the udunits file

NB The log file is a .prt file with the same name as the scenario and can be found in the ModelOut directory. The warning will be listed at the bottom of the file
However, if the warning in step 7) appears at step 4), then something is amiss.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Fates does not read the file from the UDUNITS-PATH in the scenario .cfg file

item.title: [EMMTC-84] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Do Not install the oil database under OWM. Most OSCAR users do not have this or know what it is.
item.description:
Test as follows:

  1. Run the MEMW installer.
  2. Select/change the Workspace folder, preferably to some non-default location.
  3. When selecting database folder is offered:
    • Verify that the proposed path is the "Databases" below the selected path from step 2.
  4. Finish the installation.
    • Verify that all database files are stored in the folder indicated at step 3. (chemdb.mdb, keys.mdb, Natural Resources.mdb, oildbase.mdb, Responsedb.mdb, Species.mdb, Statfjord.composition)
    • Start the newly installed MEMW and try to access the database, e.g. the profile or components editor.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Do Not install the oil database under OWM. Most OSCAR users do not have this or know what it is.

item.title: [EMMTC-75] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Bug #2 in smoothing/contouring tool: freeze in vertical cross section
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Run a simulation in OSCAR with oil in the water column.
  2. Visualize concentration grid and go to an arbitrary time step.
  3. View a cross-section.
  4. Enable smoothing.
  5. Play the rest of the simulation.
  6. Observe that the vertical cross section is updated for each output time step and NOT frozen.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Bug #2 in smoothing/contouring tool: freeze in vertical cross section

item.title: [EMMTC-100] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Stochastic logfile crash
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Create a stochastic simulation. (Any will do.)
  2. Create more than 15 log times for the simulations.
  3. Run simulation.

Acceptance criteria:

  1. Observe that Fates creates the log files with the names .t01.log, t02.log, etc.
  2. Observe that Fates does not crash after creating the 15th log file.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Stochastic logfile crash

item.title: [EMMTC-85] TEST 6.6 RC1 - FB989 / attached heavy metals: feature missing from MEMW 6.5 beta
item.description:
To confirm that this feature is present:

  1. Open MEMW
  2. go to System > Component editor...
  3. click Database > New...
    • check if EIF attached heavy metals is available as a choice under Component sources. See attached screenshot.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - FB989 / attached heavy metals: feature missing from MEMW 6.5 beta

item.title: [EMMTC-80] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Failure to create statistical output
item.description:
Test case:

  1. Create any stochastic scenario in OSCAR.
  2. In the stochastic simulation set-up, select a number of simulations less than the number of parallel runs. For example: Parallel runs = 2, simulations = 1
  3. Run the stochastic simulation.
  4. Observe an error message: "Number of simulations needs to be equal to or larger than the number of parallel runs".
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Failure to create statistical output

item.title: [EMMTC-78] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Clean up Species database
item.description:
To check that the right database is installed do the following:

  1. Open MEMW
  2. Go to System/Species Editor (see attached picture).
  3. When opening the pull down menu for choosing species, only two options should be available: Cod and Pollock.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Clean up Species database

item.title: [EMMTC-82] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Gas rate and GOR is wrongly recalculated depending on duration
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Create a simulation with a release of 100 cu.m/day, duration 10 days.
  2. Set up a gas rate of GOR 100, duration 1 day.
  3. Change the gas rate to 2 days.
  4. Observe that the RATE and GOR are not re-calculated.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Gas rate and GOR is wrongly recalculated depending on duration

item.title: [EMMTC-101] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Profile in chem.db which shall not be part of release
item.description:
Test description:
Check that only Statfjord and EIF_Test are profiles delivered with the release's chemdb
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Profile in chem.db which shall not be part of release

item.title: [EMMTC-96] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Wrong unit on vertical axis for time series of EIF in memw.xls
item.description:
1. Run a scenario, DREAM or OSCAR (make sure hat you have a limited maximum depth in your concentration and expanding grids turned off)
  2. Run "create risk map" for the water column
  3. Start MEMW.xls for the risk results and choose water column risk
  4. Check axis label on vertical axis in chart "Graph 2- Time development EIFs"
    • Should not include % any longer
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Wrong unit on vertical axis for time series of EIF in memw.xls

comments.comment: When running the test, MEMW.xls fails with "Run-time error '13': Type mismatch'.

Should be re-tested in the next test iteration. The Memw.xls will be updated from the release branch of the Excel_Makro repo.
If error 13 reappear, make FogBugz case (could be that formatting columns need to be changed in Fates as well).

item.title: [EMMTC-99] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Double sided risk curve for grain size change in sediment
item.description:
Test description
There are six attached scenario files, three for increasing grain size (A, B and C), three for decreasing grain size (D, E and F). Running one of each is probably sufficient. The test procedure is the same for all scenarios.
Each scenario is set up with only one cell in the sediment grid, and constructed so that the thickness of the sediment will be at least 30 mm within that cell. The median grain size in the sediment is calculated from the top 30 mm of the sediment, so thus the median in the sediment will be the same as the median in the release.

  1. Use the attached grid files, and run the required scenario.
  2. Go to Tools -> Create Risk Map..., select Risk for sediment and Use double-sided risk curve, and press Go, then close when the calculation is finished.
  3. Under Setup -> Model parameters you will find the grain size in the natural sediment. By viewing Sediment Concentrations -> Grain size, and move the simulation forward, you can use the Interrogate tool (pointer with question mark) to find the median grain size in the sediment after the end of the release.
  4. To calculate the risk from these two numbers, refer to the attached excel sheet, the recipe is described in the yellow box.
  5. To view the results of the risk calculation in MEMW, go to Output -> Risk Calculation Results -> Sediment Risk -> Grain-size change, move to an arbitrary time step, then use the Time Series tool to view the risk as a function of time. It should start very close to the value found from the Excel sheet, and then decrease as time goes on and reach zero after approximately five years.

The decrease in risk is partially due to mixing of the sediment, partially due to the system adapting to the new grain size.

NB
Check the mother case EMMTC-46 for some additional comments about the accuracy of the test.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Double sided risk curve for grain size change in sediment

item.title: [EMMTC-93] TEST 6.6 RC1 - EIF produced water testcase
item.description:
Test procedure

  1. Kopier inn lokasjon "EIF-Produsertvann-testcase" fra:
    I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_DREAM\
  2. Kopier inn kjemikaliedatabasen "chemdb-testsett-prodvann.mdb" fra samme mappe.
  3. Kjør scenariene for Snorre, Visund, Norne, Sleipner og beregn risk i vannkolonne.
  4. Ta opp resultater i MEMW.xls, og kopier inn bidrag til risiko og beregnet EIF i resultatfil: Resultater-EIF-test-nye-versjoner-oppdat-xx.xls

In each scenario, after Fates finished:

  • Tools > Create Risk Map Select: Risk for water column (Include particulate materials auto-selected)
  • Select: Momentary and time averaged risk
    In memw.xls:
  • Add-ins > MEMW > New workbook
  • Check "standard file path" is correct
  • Name of MEMW Location: EIF-Produsertvann-testcase
  • Name of Scenario: Snorre-*6-5 (etc...)
  • Select: EIF presentations for Water column risk [Accept Values]

To copy results into the summary sheet called "EIF-sammenlign" in Resultater-EIF-test-nye-versjoner-oppdat-xx.xls, create a new column for the tested version. Then do the following on the memw.xls from each scenario:

  1. Select sheet "Chart_watcol".
  2. Check that the listed EIF component names are identical to those in Resultater.
  3. Copy the values from the column "Contribution to risk" and paste those as the results into Resultater.
  4. Enter the number marked "Computed max. EIF", rounded to a whole number, as the EIF value in Resultater.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - EIF produced water testcase

item.title: [EMMTC-91] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Fredrikstad case - testing of dumping process
item.description:
Test Description
This test case is described in detail in the document "Test case - Fredrikstad Dumping.docx" that is attached below.

Dependencies
Current data for Fredrikstad can be copied from folder
/teradisk/DriverData/Currents/Fredrikstad_2011/
on the server 'pepper.matek.sintef.no'.

Notes:
In order to get the more fine-resolution map, one can:

  • Change map colors so both land and water is the same (sea) color.
    (reopen the scenario after the change).
  • Add GIS layers (Map > Layers), first "sk_land_5", then "sk_kyst_5".

Test procedure

  1. Copy the Fredrikstad-Test folder to your loc-data folder. The Fredrikstad-Test folder is found here: I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_DREAM
  2. Also copy the chemdb-Fredrikstad and the keys database to your Database folder.
  3. Open the scenario called Mokkalasset46mSvaleskjaer38m-MEMWx.x.prv and rename it with the correct version number (and Fates date).
  4. Run the scenario and fill in the document "Test case - Fredrikstad Dumping.docx".
  5. Use the same keys as previous figures (see document).
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Fredrikstad case - testing of dumping process

item.title: [EMMTC-107] TEST 6.6 RC1 - [Task 2.1.3] Calculate time averaged EIF in addition to maxium EIF
item.description:
Test description:

  1. Run a DREAM PW scenario.
  2. Run Create Risk Map for the water column.
  3. Open MEMW.xls and choose the run scenario and "EIF presentations for: Water column risk"
    Check sheets risk-times and Chart_watcol: they are supposed to contain the time averaged EIF in columns D2 and E2.
  4. The comulted max EIF in B2 is NOT rounded to an INT neiter are the weighted values in column F and I respectively.
  5. The chart on sheet Pie_chart is supposed to be expanded to full visibility (doesn't need to be magnified manually), the tiles contains 3 entries (max, time averaged and weighted EIF) and no zero entries are displayed as data labels.
  6. Change the weight of a component in Chart_watcol, click UpdateChart and re-check the pie chart.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - [Task 2.1.3] Calculate time averaged EIF in addition to maxium EIF

item.title: [EMMTC-71] TEST 6.6 RC1 - OSS Data assimilation (oil slick update) improvement
item.description:

item.title: [EMMTC-95] TEST 6.6 RC1- Drilling test: Chikchi-testcase
item.description:
Test procedure

  1. Copy the location "Testcase-Release Drilling" and the database "chemdb-drilling-test-nov08.mbd" from I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\Testsett_DREAM\
  2. Run the scenario attached to this case.

Visual inspection: Sediment

  1. Display Sediment Thickness, and move the simulation to the end, which should be at 3656 days, 5 hours and 51 minutes.
    • The results should look like the attached image.
  2. Display Sediment Mass/area, and move the simulation to the end, which should be at 3656 days, 5 hours and 51 minutes.
    • The results should look like the attached image.
  3. Display Sediment Grainsize, and move the simulation to the end, which should be at 3656 days, 5 hours and 51 minutes.
    • The results should look like the attached image.

Visual inspection: Concentration

  1. Display concentration of all components by selecting both Max and Total concentration. Move simulation to 1 day 9 hours.
    • Place a vertical cross section approximately as seen in the figure, and verify that the results look similar.
    • Check that the units match.
  2. Display concentration of the component Drill-PolyamineClay by selecting both Max and Total concentration, and then using the Select Component button. Move simulation to 1 day 9 hours.
    • Place a vertical cross section approximately as seen in the figure, and verify that the results look similar.
    • Check that the units match.

Visual inspection: Submerged particles

  1. Display submerged particles, with fixed size 3 pixels.
  2. Move simulation forward to 1 day, 4 hours.
  3. Place a vertical cross section as shown in the image.
    • Verify that the results look similar.
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1- Drilling test: Chikchi-testcase

item.title: [EMMTC-73] TEST 6.6 RC1 - Investigate possible issue with NetCDF-imported currents
item.description:
Test case uploaded to
I:\organisasjon\8016-Marin_miljoteknologi\Sak\0-Org\05_Faglag\Miljømodellering\Installations\Release testing\TestCases\fb1253_netCDF_to_hyd_conversion
See readme file for instructions.
Note that this test case requires running a Python script which uses several 3rd party Python libraries. Both Python and these libraries can be obtained by installing python(x,y): https://code.google.com/p/pythonxy/
item.summary: TEST 6.6 RC1 - Investigate possible issue with NetCDF-imported currents
